titleproper.value:
Guide to the Girls' High School collection
                    <num>ARC.128</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Nicholas Pavlik

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2011-11-23T11:27-0500</date>

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: Girls' High School was Brooklyn's first all-girls high school, opening in 1886 on Nostrand Avenue between Macon and Halsey Streets in the Brooklyn neighborhood of Bedford-Stuyvesant. In 1976 the school merged with its counterpart, Boys' High School, and opened at 1700 Fulton Street as Boys and Girls High School. The Girls' High School collection spans the period 1899 to 1936 and contains volumes, journals, and ephemera documenting school events and student activities.

p.value: Identification of item, date (if known); Girls' High School collection, ARC.128, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

Portions of accession 1985.054 were the gifts of Grace E. Beadman, 1937, and Sophie E. Rie, 1986. Accession 2006.031 was the gift of Marjorie Smeltzer-Stevenot, 2006. Sources and dates of acquisition for remaining items in the collection are unknown.

Although Girls' High School closed in 1964, it later merged with Boys' High School and reopened in 1976 under its new name, Boys and Girls High School, at 1700 Fulton Street. As of 2010, the school continues to operate at this location.

The Girls' High School collection spans the period 1899 to 1936 and contains volumes, journals, and ephemera documenting school events and student activities. Materials include two exercise programs for class events; a collection of school songs; three yearbooks under the title 
                <emph render="italic">The Triennial</emph>; a theatrical program for 
                <emph render="italic">Old Heidelberg</emph>; a play put on by the dramatic societies of Girls' and Boys' High Schools; issues of the student-produced literary journal, 
                <emph render="italic">Blue and Gold</emph>; issues of the school's newsletter, published under the titles 
                <emph render="italic">The Chaser Fortnightly</emph> and 
                <emph render="italic">The Fortnightly</emph>; and two volumes of poems written by students.
